claim: French people do not have bad breath.

supporting.text: Oral hygiene practices, such as regular brushing and flossing, are widely adopted in France, reducing the likelihood of bad breath.

attacks.text: Oral hygiene practices, such as regular brushing and flossing, are widely adopted in France, reducing the likelihood of bad breath.
Not all French people adhere to oral hygiene practices consistently; some may neglect brushing or flossing.
Studies show that cultural emphasis on dental care in France leads to high compliance with oral hygiene routines.
Dietary habits, such as consumption of garlic and cheese, can contribute to bad breath regardless of oral hygiene.
French cuisine includes breath-freshening foods like parsley and mint, which counteract strong-smelling ingredients.

supporting.text: Access to dental care is high in France, which helps maintain good oral health and prevents conditions that cause bad breath.

attacks.text: Access to dental care is high in France, which helps maintain good oral health and prevents conditions that cause bad breath.
High access to dental care does not guarantee that all individuals utilize these services regularly or effectively.
Public health campaigns in France promote regular dental check-ups, increasing the likelihood of service utilization.
Other factors like diet, smoking, and alcohol consumption can contribute to bad breath independently of dental care access.
France has lower smoking rates compared to many other countries, reducing this risk factor for bad breath.

supporting.text: Dietary habits in France, including low consumption of strongly odorous foods like garlic and onions, contribute to better breath.

attacks.text: Dietary habits in France, including low consumption of strongly odorous foods like garlic and onions, contribute to better breath.
French cuisine often includes garlic and onions, which are known to cause bad breath when consumed frequently.
While garlic and onions are used in French cuisine, they are typically cooked in ways that reduce their odor impact compared to raw consumption.
Bad breath is primarily caused by oral hygiene practices rather than diet alone.
Oral hygiene practices in France are generally good, with high rates of regular dental check-ups and brushing habits.

supporting.text: Cultural emphasis on personal grooming and hygiene in France includes attention to oral care, minimizing bad breath.

attacks.text: Cultural emphasis on personal grooming and hygiene in France includes attention to oral care, minimizing bad breath.
Not all individuals in France adhere to cultural norms of hygiene, leading to cases of bad breath despite general trends.
Studies show that socioeconomic factors can limit access to oral care products, even in countries with strong hygiene cultures.
Dietary habits in France, such as consumption of garlic and wine, can contribute to bad breath regardless of oral hygiene practices.
Regular use of mouthwash and breath fresheners is common in France, counteracting dietary causes of bad breath.
